fields.description:
Can we please retain the "Test Connection" button on the Create Directory Connector - Connector tab and also the "Test Search" button on the Create Directory Connector - Configuration tab after the directory has been added. That would assist some users who have configured the incorrect Base DN in the first instance and want to try again.

Thanks,
Nick

fields.description:
Some use-cases require the ability to add a new application using the SOAP (or other remote) API.

This capability should be protected by a "Can Create Another Application" permission, which defaults to {{false}}, and the newly created application should inherit the permissions of the application under whose aegis it was created.
fields.summary: Add ability to create an application to the remote API

fields.description: When saving a backup of the Crowd database to an XML file, then restoring the backup, the carriage return formatting of the email template is lost, so everything in the message ends up on one line.
fields.summary: Email template format lost when restoring backup of Crowd database

fields.description: We need to do a better job of catching LDAP-related exceptions.

fields.description:
To replicate:

1.  Take Crowd 1.0.x backup that associates an AD directory with the Crowd application.
2.  Restore to 1.4.4 instance.

This will cause a NumberFormatException due to an empty string being returned and Crowd attempting to convert this to an int value.
fields.summary: XML Imports from 1.0.x versions of Crowd do not contain the ldap.pagedresults.size attribute.  This causes an exception in certain cases.

fields.description:
Have JIRA setup to get emails for support.  Would like jira to create users for each email (project=SITE, issuetype=1, createusers=true, bulk=forward).  However, JIRA can not create a user in crowd it seems.   This makes crowd totally useless for us.  

We are using using crowd for 3 atlassian products and 2 apache installs.  It works great, but we have to be able to get email from users and reply to them.  

Please help
fields.summary: Unable to use email gateway

fields.description:
A valid CSV file import fails (exception thrown) if it contains a column that is unmapped.
{noformat}
username,first name,last name,email,groups
delme,del,me,del.me@asdf.com,agroup
{noformat}

If this would work one could use the same file for the user and group mapping just buy choosing the appropriate columns from each.

Another annoyance: I can't find a way to import users into more than one group at a time.
fields.summary: CSV import fails if a column is unmapped.

fields.description:

http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DEVNET/List+of+Product+Dependencies

Also consider whether we should add a list of the minimal dependencies, as requested here:
http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?forumID=104&threadID=25833
fields.summary: List of Crowd dependencies

fields.description:
It would be very useful if token expiration times could be configured per application.

We have two desktop applications under development, which both require that user's authentication token is valid for a long time. Since we use Crowd for web application SSO the timeout is set to few hours which is not enough for the desktop applications. Now we have to work around the problem by implementing a keep-alive thread that keeps each authentication token valid by refreshing it with Crowd. This creates unnecessary load and feels like a bad solution. A more elegant way would be to keep the expiration handling in Crowd.

I created a new issue for this, since http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CWD-340 seems to request configurable application timeouts in SSO context. In this case there is no need for SSO because user can't switch for application to another.
fields.summary: Custom token expiration time per application

fields.description:
When using Crowd 1.4.4 with JDK 1.6 it is not possible to run Crowd's console and Demo app in the same time.

How to reproduce:
Environment: In a Windows or Linux machine with JDK 1.6 
Steps:
1. Start Crowd.
2. Access url localhost:8095/crowd. It works fine.
3. Access url localhost:8095/demo. A HTTP 500 error page is shown. See the logs and error page attached.

Inverting steps 2 and 3 will cause the demo to work fine and Crowd console show the error page.
fields.summary: Using JDK 1.6 Crowd console and Demo App don't work together

fields.description:
In Bamboo we have two config files for ehcache - ehcache.xml and crowd-ehcache.xml.

In the CacheManagerImpl constructor, the cache manager retrieved is actually the one Bamboo created for its caches with our default settings.

If you have specific caches specified in the crowd-ehcache.xml file, these are then created correctly.  if you don't, Crowd will use bamboo's cache manager to create the default CROWD_CACHE rather than create the default cache using the default properties in the crowd-ehcache.xml.  Bamboo's default cache is set to eternal=true=bad!!!.

The work around for this is to explicitly define the cache in the crowd config file.
fields.summary: If crowd-ehcache.xml is misconfigured, Bamboo Crowd Integration Client uses wrong default cache

fields.description:
Using the SecurityServerClient addPrincipal() method when integrating with our application lets us add more principals into Crowd than the Crowd installation's license allows.  Once we reach that limit no users can log in to Crowd for SSO, nor can the Crowd admin user log in to delete some of them.

Ideally addPrincipal() should throw some sort of exception we can catch and prevent adding above and beyond the limit.
fields.summary: SecurityServerClient.addPrincipal() allows adding more principals than the installation's license allows.

fields.description: We've reached the maximum number of Principals in Crowd for our license and now we can't even log in to the Administration Console as the Admin user to delete some of them.
fields.summary: When the maximum number of Principals is reached, Crowd Console should allow admin user to log in

fields.summary: Not able to import users from JIRA into CROWD
Certain LDAP-related errors that generate XFireRuntimeExceptions can actually cause JIRA's comment field to not appear.

fields.description:
If you import users from an LDAP server into a delegated directory, the usernames are imported in lowercase.  

   http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CWD-876

As a result, the usernames used in JIRA or Confluence will be in lowercase.  Since data in both apps link to the username, switching to an LDAP directory connector that may contain mixed case usernames for the same user will cause problems.  Until this option is added to Crowd,

   http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CWD-876

we need to let customers know about the possible danger of switching between the two.
fields.summary: Need to update delegated directory documentation to let customers know they cannot toggle between using delegated and LDAP directories since delegated usernames are lowercase.
Need to update cache before modifying directory (e.g. adding users to group) via client application.

fields.description:
A number of AD/Crowd customers have reported errors when either browsing groups or using authentication testing in Crowd:

org.springframework.ldap.BadLdapGrammarException: Failed to parse DN; nested exception is org.springframework.ldap.core.TokenMgrError: Lexical error at line....
fields.summary: BadLdapGrammarException occurs when Crowd attempts to read a DN

fields.description:
When using Crowd in Tomcat, the property {{useBodyEncodingForURI="true"}} needs to be set in the {{server.xml}} if user or group names contain unicode characters. This is done for the standalone release of Crowd.

Users of the EAR/WAR version in Tomcat need this documented. The [JIRA documentation|http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/docs/v3.12.3/servers/tomcat55.html#Modify+Tomcat+server.xml] is a good template.
fields.summary: Document use of useBodyEncodingForURI for Tomcat deployments of EAR/WAR

fields.description: If we are going to support Google Apps and their SAML implementation it would be great to support the WebEx implementation too.
fields.summary: Support WebEx SAML
Crowd Search API currently allows searches for PRINCIPAL_FULLNAME on Crowd internal directories, not LDAP

fields.description:
If the proxy address is not added to the remote address list the following error appears.

    SOAPService: Client host is invalid:
fields.summary: Trusted Proxy values also need to be added to application remote address list or application receives "Client host is invalid" error

fields.description:
The SearchContext is an overloaded object used to define search restrictions for both internal and external (SecurityServerClient) searches.

We should split the implementation: SearchContext, and InternalSearchContext extends SearchContext.

For example, searching via directory ID is not permissible in the external SearchContext but is defined on the InternalSearchContext.
fields.summary: SecurityServerClient search restrictions should only expose those which are offered to the remote API

fields.description:
A number of AD/Crowd customers have reported errors when either browsing groups or using authentication testing in Crowd:

   org.springframework.ldap.BadLdapGrammarException: Failed to parse DN; nested exception is org.springframework.ldap.core.TokenMgrError: Lexical error at line....
fields.summary: Issues exist with DNs or Group Names that contain special characters

fields.description:
The SecurityServerClient API could use some improvements:

Have a complete, symmetrical API across all the SOAPEntity types (Principal, Group, Role). This should include at least the following (examples for Principal only):
addPrincipal(SOAPPrincipal)
removePrincipal(SOAPPrincipal)
updatePrincipal(SOAPPrincipal)

Have the SecurityServerClient use Lists rather than Arrays when returning collections of SOAPEntities. Even if this is only outward-facing and handled as Arrays internally, that is fine. Failing that, a Util class would be nice for wrestling with arrays. See [this thread|http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257284097&#257284097] for details.
fields.summary: Improve the SecurityServerClient API, possibly the SOAP API also

fields.description:
It is not possible to set the active flag via the remote API for principals and roles (but it is possible for groups).

Add methods: updatePrincipal(String name, boolean active); updateRole(String name, String description, boolean active).
fields.summary: SecurityServerClient API does not allow the update of active flag for principals or roles

fields.description:
Customer experiences documented in CWD-125 suggest that setting up Crowd with Lotus Domino is now fairly painless.

It may be worth updating our documentation to say that customers have had success with it. I'd prefer not to make it officially supported as we don't have a test environment in-house.
fields.summary: Document that customers have had success using Crowd with Lotus Domino

fields.description:
We went live with Crowd last Friday (June 27th) and when I came into work today I had complaints about JIRA (we are on 3.12.1) response times being slow.  I also had complaints about users being logged in then kicked out and not being able to login in again.  When I looked at the logs I noticed that crowd was not able to connect to the database.  This problem seemed to fix it self with out me doing anything.  I also noticed a lot of deadlock errors.  We have since rolled back going live on crowd until we can get these issues resolved.  I'm including the crowd log file with the errors.

Also I will be out of the office until July 7th, so if you need any information from us please contact Jonah Lund at jlund@idsgrp.com.  Thanks
fields.summary: Database Connection Issues

fields.description:
When one creates an internal directory (including in the setup wizard), one of the options is the "password encryption" type:

!crowd_encryption.png!

As you can see, we default to "atlassian-sha1", and the note below virtually insists on it (who would install Crowd if they *didn't* want "compatibility between Atlassian products"?).

This is terrible, because we're effectively locking user passwords into a proprietary format. In particular, LDAP directories don't support 'atlassian-sha1', which means users of the internal directory cannot migrate to a proper LDAP implementation, without losing their passwords.
fields.summary: Default to sha1 hashes rather than the infrequently implemented atlassian-sha1

At the moment it is not passible to differ the groups/principals/roles which are defined on different directories.

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Status as of 6 September 2013|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3C78B5| titleBGColor=#3C78B5| bgColor=#E7F4FA}

Hi everyone,
A big thank you for the feedback you've provided on this feature request. 
We've been working on this issue and have good news: from Crowd 2.7 (soon to be released), you'll be able to rename users (i.e. usernames) in Crowd's internal directories. 

Crowd will also detect any renames that are made in a remote directory, including LDAP servers.

If you have any further feedback or improvement requests around this topic, please create a separate issue as we will be closing this one.

Thanks again for your continued support,
Helen Hung
Atlassian Product Management

{panel}

Explore the possibility of either changing/renaming users in Crowd.
fields.summary: Provide ability to rename users in Crowd.

fields.description:
The SOAPPrincipalHelper is a util class which has no state nor dependencies.

Makes more sense to go with static methods for ease of use.
fields.summary: Make SOAPPrincipalHelper static

fields.description:
When a principal that does not exist internally for a delegated directory is successfully authenticated with the LDAP directory, it is automatically added to the internal database. The addPrincipal method is called using a RemotePrincipal parameter that does not have the directoryID property populated (directoryID = 0).

The directoryID should correspond to the ID of the delegated directory.

Refer to discussion: http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?messageID=257282986
fields.summary: The directoryID is not populated on principals added automatically after authentication with a delegated directory

fields.description:
Currently the attribute/values are displayed on the directory in the console.

It would be more user-friendly to display standard properties as well as the attribute/value pairs for custom subclasses of the Crowd-provided directory connectors, ie. show the LDAP connection properties for a custom LDAP directory, etc.
fields.summary: Custom directories that are subclasses should display a UI similar to the standard directories
Provide support for TLS encryption

fields.description:
When using Crowd, Jira, LDAP, and automatic signup through JIRA the Fullname field in the sign up screen in Jira is parsed into LDAP equivalent givenName and SN. However, if users enter a single name into the form the SN is not populated. In LDAP person which is part of inetOrgPerson, SN is a required field. Since it is not populated Jira throws an exception.

I cannot find any mention of this problem though it is likely to happen anywhere that the Jira sign up screen is used with LDAP integration. I am very happy to use a workaround the duplicates on of the other fields but throwing an error when a field like fullname is parsed into two fields must be happening to other folks.

If you are an administrator, please try submitting this problem via the Support Request Page

fields.summary: When using Crowd, Jira, LDAP, and automatic signup through JIRA the Fullname field is parsed but users enter a single name and SN is not populated.

fields.description:
The 'contract' says that we should be returning null from the GroupMembershipManager, unfortunately this method isn't checking for null on returned group name.

I think we may change the 'contract' here, since returning an empty list is a lot safer and a little more risk free.
fields.summary: CrowdUserDetailsServiceImpl.generateAuthoritiesFromGroupNames throws a NullPointer if no groups are associated

fields.description:
Administration > Current Sessions >  User Sessions( Session Browser) the link to the users associated Directory is using the wrong id. It is using the TOKEN table ID and not the TOKEN table DIRECTORYID.

In the URL "/crowd/console/secure/directory/viewinternal.action?ID="


its a quick fix probably b/c it is just a JSP change
fields.summary: Administration > Current Sessions >  User Sessions( Session Browser) the link to the users associated Directory is using the wrong id.

fields.description:
When using resetPrincipalCredential(), if the Exchange SMTP server rejects the email address, then all we get from resetPrincipalCredential() is the exception:

  org.codehaus.xfire.XFireRuntimeException: Could not invoke service.. Nested exception is org.codehaus.xfire.fault.XFireFault: Invalid Addresses

Our company's Exchange server is configured to reject any SMTP emails addressed outside the company.  Addresses inside work okay, but with the above exception we can't easily catch those to format a user-friendly error message.
fields.summary: Unhelpful Exception with resetPrincipalCredential() when SMTP Server rejects email address

fields.description: At present, if using an LDAP directory, Crowd writes the username value to JIRA/Confluence in the method retrieved from the LDAP directory (e.g. mixed case).  Since JIRA/Confluence enforce lowercase usernames for internal user management, it would be helpful to allow Crowd admins enable lowercase conversion for JIRA/Confluence.
fields.summary: Allow Crowd admin to specify property to enforce toLower on username for JIRA/Confluence integration

fields.description:
To improve performance with Crowd, a JIRA connector is needed that supports massive amounts of users.

To accomplish this, a JIRA connector can be wrote that downloads a user's details and group memberships and inserts the data into JIRA upon a successful authentication.
fields.summary: JIRA Crowd user syncronizer

fields.description:
Create a directory connector that allows you to use another Crowd server as the user / group / role repository.

This could be done one of two ways:

# The RemoteDirectory interface maps up 1-to-1 with the SecurityServer interface.
# Have one Crowd server directy interact with an external Crowd's db (for better performance and token reuse).
fields.summary: Crowd to Crowd authentication connector

fields.description:
Create an option for applications on their configuration screen to specify a specific domain, rather than a global domain.

When SOAP clients then call 'getDomain()', the call would check for any specific app domain, if no domain is not specified, then the global crowd domain would be used.
fields.summary: Per-application cookies.

fields.description:
The admin GUI allows creation of groups with '&' in the name but then won't let you delete them showing error:

"Failed to find com.atlassian.crowd.integration.model.RemoteGroup DirectoryID: 5963778 and name: POMG Strategy "

where group name is 'POMG Strategy & Planning'
fields.summary: Groups can be created with '&' in name but cannot subsequently be deleted

fields.description:
Had a customer make an great point.  In the flow chart on this page

  http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Specifying+the+Directory+Order+for+an+Application

it appears that Crowd will not search both directories added to the application.  This is not true.  In order for Crowd to determine if the username exists in both directories and flatten group memberships, it will hit all directories attached to the application to flatten the group memberships under the username as defined on this page:

  http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Editing+a+User%27s+Group+and+Role+Membership
fields.summary: Need to modify the flow chart on the "Specify Directory Order" page
Checking if a user is a member of a group on large user ldap directories is slow and casuses OutOfMemoryException -- FAIL
JIRA Performance with Crowd 1.4.3 and AD is very slow

fields.description:
We are using Crowd with Confluence. Confluence has UI where user can search for groups using wildcards eg: "atla*". This doesn't work with Crowd.

See CrowdEntityQueryParser.class method SearchResult findGroups(Query query). Only one group is returned if it matches the search string. The wildcard part of query is ignored.
fields.summary: CrowdEntityQueryParser doesn't search groups by wildcards

fields.summary: Attempting to add groups to ApacheDS in Crowd throws LDAP: error code 21 exception

fields.description:
Just stumbled across this today trying to export our Crowd instance for support to try to replicate a problem with Crowd and JIRA.

Our custom directory extends InternalDirectory. It relies on Crowd to autowire our custom directory as it would an InternalDirectory. Our subclass uses the InternalDirectory superclass to store Principals, Groups, and Roles in Crowd's MySQL database.

An export should take into account the fact our subclass is an instanceof InternalDirectory and export our Entities as though they are from an InternalDirectory.
fields.summary: XML exporter should export Principal, Group, and Role data for InternalDirectory subclasses

fields.description: Currently we throw an {{UnsupportedOperationException}} when Confluence is not allowed to add or modify a user in a Crowd directory. Instead we should implement {{isCreative()}} and {{isReadOnly()}} correctly.
fields.summary: Implement the atlassian-user isCreative() call properly
Default Generic LDAP connector attributes for groups are incorrect

fields.description: For example, if an LDAP user have multiple mail attributes, we might not be to guarantee which mail attribute will be used as the user's primary email address.
fields.summary: Enforce attribute ordering if there are multiple attributes with the same name

fields.description:
I have an instance of Crowd 1.4.2, with a connector to a Microsoft Active Directory Server running on Windows 2003 R2 SP 2.
We have many groups in our AD -- so many that they're unwieldy to work with all at once. So I created an OU containing only the groups I need. I used this OU as filter by referencing it in my base DN for groups in the connector configurator: ou=Extranet,ou=Groups.

In one way, this works. If I view the list of available groups in Crowd for that directory, it shows just what it should -- the 6 groups I care about. But if I bring up a user record and examine their groups, I see ALL the AD groups they're a part of, not just the filtered ones I care about. If I click into such a group, I do get an inspect/edit screen, but with a red warning bar. If I click from that group into a list of  its users, I see nothing.

Likewise in Jira, which I integrated with Crowd, I get similar behavior in terms of seeing the additional groups, and being led to belive I can edit/inspect them, then getting warnings and failures.

fields.description:
The fetchDirectMembers method of the RFC2307MemberParser class doesn't check whether the returned member from getMember is null before adding it to the list of return values.  Multiple conditions can cause the returned value to be null, including at least:

* The listed member object wasn't found in the directory tree
* There is more than one object in the directory tree that matches the name listed

If a null value is part of the returned list from fetchDirectMembers, this will cause a NullPointerException later down the line, for example:

2008-05-30 15:51:08,878 http-8095-Processor24 INFO [integration.directory.connector.Rfc2307] Performing principal search: baseDN = dc=datasynapse,dc=com - filter = (&(uid=emergency)(&(objectClass=posixAccount)(!(uid=*$))(title=*)))
2008-05-30 15:51:08,921 http-8095-Processor21 INFO [integration.directory.connector.Rfc2307] Performing group search: baseDN = ou=groups,dc=datasynapse,dc=com - filter = (objectclass=posixGroup)

fields.description:
I would like to restrict default access to one set of groups, but allow access to some sub-trees to other groups.  However this does not seem to be possible.  My test config is this:
{code}
        <Location /svn>
                DAV svn
                SVNPath /opt/repository

                AuthType Basic
                AuthName "Atlassian Subversion Repository"

                PerlAuthenHandler Apache::CrowdAuth
                PerlSetVar CrowdAppName svn-repo-test
                PerlSetVar CrowdAppPassword xxxx
                PerlSetVar CrowdSOAPURL https://extranet.atlassian.com/crowd/services/SecurityServer
                PerlSetVar CrowdCacheEnabled on
                PerlSetVar CrowdCacheLocation /tmp/CrowdAuth-private
                PerlSetVar CrowdCacheExpiry 30

                PerlAuthzHandler Apache::CrowdAuthz
                PerlSetVar CrowdAllowedGroups atlassian-xplatform

                Require valid-user

        </Location>

        <Location /svn/sysadmin>
                PerlAuthzHandler Apache::CrowdAuthz
                PerlSetVar CrowdAllowedGroups atlassian-sysadmin
                PerlSetVar CrowdAllowedUsers ssmith
        </Location>
{code}
In this configuration neither the atlassian-sysadmin or ssmith can access the sysadmin subtree.

fields.description:
Internally, we have a domain we use and externally we have a domain we use.

IE: *.company.com and *.internal.local

We would like to be able to use crowd SSO for both (knowing that we'll have to login to both of the sets once each).

Right now, we have SSO only enabled on the external domains and have to re-login to all the internal ones.
